MINUTE ENTRY for proceedings held before Judge Jennifer G Zipps: Scheduling Conference held on 6/12/2023.Parties heard regarding rescheduling of the motion hearing for preliminary injunction. Parties agree the hearing should last no more than 3 hours. For reasons set forth on the record, the Amended Motion to Reschedule Hearing by Defendant Horne 66 is granted. The motion hearing on Plaintiffs' Motion for Preliminary Injunction 3 is reset for July 10, 2023 at 1:30 p.m. in Courtroom 5D, 405 West Congress Street, Tucson, Arizona 85701 before the Honorable Jennifer G. Zipps. Additionally, the Court will hear argument on the Defendant Gregory School's Motion to Dismiss 37 at the July 10 hearing. 90 minutes will be allocated to Plaintiffs and 90 minutes will be allocated to Defendants and Intervenors.In light of the parties' decision to present declarations in lieu of witness testimony, each party is directed to submit a statement identifying the documentary exhibits and declarations that the party intends to rely on for purposes of the hearing by close of business on June 29, 2023. If those documents are already in the record, they need not be re-filed but the party must specifically identify where each document may be found. Any exhibit or declaration that is not yet in the record must be filed on or before June 29, 2023. Proposed findings of fact and conclusions of law are due on or before July 5, 2023. Parties are relieved of the obligation to submit a joint pre-hearing statement. APPEARANCES: Telephonic appearance by Colin Matthew Proksel, Justin R. Rassi, and Rachel Berg for Plaintiffs; Karl McKay Worthington and Maria Syms for Defendant Horne; David Calvin Potts for defendant Gregory School; Kristian Eric Nelson and Greg Clifton for defendant Arizona Interscholastic Association Incorporated; Dean John Sauer and Justin D. Smith for Intervenors. (Court Reporter Aaron LaDuke.) Hearing held 2:04 pm to 2:36 pm. This is a TEXT ENTRY ONLY. There is no PDF document associated with this entry. (SVC) (Entered: 06/14/2023)

case_data.name: Doe v. Horne
case_data.plaintiff_description: Plaintiffs are (1) an eleven-year-old transgender girl and (2) a fifteen-year-old transgender girl who were allegedly denied participation on several girls' school sports teams for being transgender.
case_data.summary:
This is a case challenging an Arizona statute (A.R.S. § 15-120.02) that excludes transgender girls from participating in school-based sports teams that align with their gender identity. On April 17, 2023, the plaintiffs — school-aged transgender teens who were denied participation on several girls' school sports teams due to their assigned sex at birth — filed suit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Arizona against the state's Superintendent of Public Instruction, the Arizona Interscholastic Association, a school district, and a private school. The plaintiffs filed suit under multiple statutes — including 42 USC § 1983 (based on alleged violations of the Fourteenth Amendment's Equal Protection Clause), Title IX, the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA), and Section 504 of the Rehabilitation Act  — claiming that the ban discriminated on the basis of transgender status, had no viable justification, and caused harm to transgender students by excluding them from social participation. The plaintiffs, represented by private counsel and the National Center for Lesbian Rights, sought declaratory and injunctive relief, as well as attorney’s fees. District Court Judge Jennifer Zipps was assigned to the case.  

The challenged statute prohibited schools from allowing transgender girls to play on girls’ teams in interscholastic competitions. In addition, the provision created a private cause of action for any student to sue a school or athletic program that breaches the law if the student believed they suffered a direct or indirect harm as a result. In their complaint, the plaintiffs alleged that the provision discriminated against the plaintiffs based on transgender status, which is a sex-based trait. They argued that because the statute does not have an “exceedingly persuasive justification,” a heightened scrutiny for classifications based on sex, it amounts to a violation of the Equal Protection Clause. 

In addition, the plaintiffs claimed that the prohibition violated Title IX by discriminating against transgender individuals. They also argued that the denial of meaningful access to sports programs ran afoul the ADA and Section 504 of the Rehabilitation Act because it constituted discrimination based on a disability (gender dysphoria). The plaintiffs alleged further that the exclusion caused them to experience stigma, denied them various benefits of participating in school sports, and “directly contribute[d] to negative physical and emotional health consequences.” 

On the same day they filed the lawsuit, the plaintiffs moved for a preliminary injunction. Members of the Arizona legislature subsequently moved to intervene in the case as defendants. On June 12, 2023, the court allowed them to intervene only to make arguments against the plaintiffs' motion for preliminary injunction. 2023 WL 3956618.

On July 20, 2023, the court granted the plaintiffs' motion for a preliminary injunction. The court found that excluding plaintiffs from school sports causes very serious injury, and emphasized that transgender girls who have not undergone male puberty do not have an athletic advantage over other girls. According to the court, the challenged statute was facially discriminatory against transgender students, and the defendants failed to demonstrate that the provision was substantially related to legitimate goals of ensuring equal opportunities for girls to play sports and to ensure safety. The court characterized the defendant's justification that the provision was necessary to protect girls’ sports as “based on overbroad generalizations and stereotypes that erroneously equate transgender statute with athletic ability.” Thus, the court found that the plaintiffs were substantially likely to succeed on their equal protection and Title IX claims. 683 F.Supp.3d 950. The defendants appealed to the Ninth Circuit Court of Appeals a day later. The district court subsequently denied the defendants' motion for a stay of the injunction pending appeal. 2023 WL 5017231.

Later that year, on December 11, the court dismissed the Title IX and Rehabilitation Act claims against one of the defendants (the private school), holding that those statutes did not apply to it. 2023 WL 11892137.

On June 21, 2024, the court denied the defendants' motion to dismiss the ADA and Rehabilitation Act claims, holding that the plaintiffs had sufficiently alleged claims because those statutes prohibit discrimination based on gender dysphoria. 2024 WL 3091984.

On September 9, 2024, the Ninth Circuit affirmed the lower court's grant of a preliminary injunction. The Ninth Circuit found that the district court did not err by concluding that the Plaintiffs would likely prevail on their Equal Protection claim. The Ninth Circuit held that the Arizona ban discriminates against transgender individuals on its face and that the defendants were unlikely to be able to adequately tie this to the important governmental objectives of preserving fair competition and equal opportunity for female student-athletes. The Ninth Circuit did not address the Title IX claims. 115 F.4th 1083

On October 22, 2024, the defendants asked the Supreme Court to hear the case. As of April 4, 2025, the petition to the Court is still pending (docket 24-449).
case_data.summary_short: On April 17, 2023, the plaintiffs — school-aged transgender teens who were denied participation on several girls' school sports teams for their assigned sex at birth under an Arizona statute — filed suit in the District of Arizona against the state's Superintendent of Public Instruction in the U.S. District Court for the District of Arizona. The plaintiffs sued under 42 USC § 1983 (based on violations of the Fourteenth Amendment's Equal Protection Clause), as well as Title IX, the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA), and Section 504 of the Rehabilitation Act, alleging that the ban discriminated on the basis of transgender status. On July 20, 2023, the court granted the plaintiffs' motion for a preliminary injunction. On September 9, 2024, the Ninth Circuit affirmed the lower court's ruling, and the defendants subsequently asked the Supreme Court to hear the case. As of April 4, 2025, the petition to the Court is still pending.

documents.text:
Case 4:23-cv-00185-JGZ   Document 160   Filed 10/23/23   Page 1 of 12
 
 
 
1  WO 
2   
3   
4   
5   
6  IN THE UNITED STATES DISTRICT COURT 
7  FOR THE DISTRICT OF ARIZONA 
 
8 
 
9  Helen Doe, et al.,  No. CV-23-00185-TUC-JGZ 
   
10  Plaintiffs,  ORDER  
   
11  v.  
 
12  Thomas C Horne, et al., 
 
13  Defendants. 
 
14   
15  Pending before the Court is a Motion to Intervene pursuant to Rule 24 of the Federal 
16  Rules of Civil Procedure filed by Anna Van Hoek, Lisa Fink, Amber Zenczak, and Arizona 
17  Women of Action (Proposed Intervenors). (Doc. 98.) Plaintiffs filed an opposition and the 
18  Proposed Intervenors filed a reply. (Docs. 130, 138.) For the following reasons, the Court 
19  will deny the Motion to Intervene. 
20  BACKGROUND 
21  In 2022, the Arizona Legislature and then-Governor Doug Ducey enacted A.R.S. § 
22  15-120.02 (the Statute), which provides that interscholastic or intramural “[a]thletic teams 
23  or sports designated for ‘females’, ‘women’ or ‘girls’ may not be open to students of the 
24  male sex.” The Statute went into effect in on September 23, 2022.  
25  Plaintiffs Jane Doe and Megan Roe are two transgender girls who attend Arizona 
26  schools and intend to try out for and participate on girls’ sports teams in the current 
27  academic year. Plaintiffs allege that the Statute violates the Equal Protection Clause of the 
28  Fourteenth Amendment, Title IX, the Americans with Disabilities Act, and Section 504 of 
 

 
Case 4:23-cv-00185-JGZ   Document 160   Filed 10/23/23   Page 2 of 12
 
 
 
1  the Rehabilitation Act. (Doc. 1.) In their April 2023 Complaint, Plaintiffs named five 
2  defendants: (1) Thomas C. Horne, in his official capacity as State Superintendent of Public 
3  Instruction; (2) Laura Toenjes, in her official capacity as Superintendent of the Kyrene 
4  School District; (3) the Kyrene School District; (4) The Gregory School, an independent 
5  school organized as a 501(c)(3) non-profit; and (5) the Arizona Interscholastic Association 
6  (AIA).1 (Id.) With their Complaint, Plaintiffs filed a Motion for a Preliminary Injunction 
7  on their Title IX and Equal Protection claims, seeking to enjoin Defendants from enforcing 
8  the Statute against them so that they may have “an equal opportunity to try out for and 
9  participate on the girls’ volleyball, soccer, basketball, and cross-country teams” during the 
10  school year while this case proceeds. (Doc. 3 at 5.) 
11  Before any defendant made an appearance, Senator Warren Peterson, President of 
12  the Arizona State Senate, and Representative Ben Toma, Speaker of the Arizona House of 
13  Representatives (the Legislators), filed a Motion to Intervene pursuant to Rule 24 of the 
14  Federal Rules of Civil Procedure. (Doc. 19.) Though the Court denied the Motion to the 
15  extent that Legislators sought to intervene  as of  right, the  Court granted permissive 
16  intervention on a limited basis to allow Legislators to present argument and evidence in 
17  opposition to Plaintiffs’ Motion for Preliminary Injunction. (Doc. 79.) Later, the Court 
18  amended its decision and allowed the Legislators to participate as a party to the litigation. 
19  (Docs. 111 & 142.) 
20  On June 30, 2023, while Plaintiffs’ Motion for Preliminary Injunction was pending 
21  before the Court, Anna Van Hoek, Lisa Fink, Amber Zenczak, and Arizona Women of 
22  Action filed the pending Motion to Intervene in the action. (Doc. 98.)  
23  On July 10, 2023, the parties to the litigation presented arguments before the Court 
24  in a hearing on Plaintiffs’ Motion for Preliminary Injunction. (Doc. 115.) The Court 
25  subsequently granted Plaintiffs’ Motion for Preliminary Injunction. (Doc. 127.)  
26  The Motion to Intervene was fully briefed as of August 4, 2023. (Doc. 138.) 
27 
 
1 Laura Toenjes and the Kyrene School District filed a Stipulation in lieu of Answer, 
28 
informing the Court that they “will not be an active participant in this case, including  
filing any response to Motions currently pending before the Court.” (Doc. 59 at 2.) 
 
- 2 - 

 
Case 4:23-cv-00185-JGZ   Document 160   Filed 10/23/23   Page 3 of 12
 
 
 
1  DISCUSSION 
I.  Intervention as of Right 
2 
The Federal Rules of Civil Procedure permit a party to intervene as of right under 
3 
Rule 24(a) and to intervene permissively under Rule 24(b). Cooper v. Newsom, 13 F.4th 
4 
857, 864 (9th Cir. 2021). A party seeking intervention of right under Rule 24(a) must 
5 
satisfy a four-part test: (1) the application must be timely; (2) the applicant must have a 
6 
“significantly protectable interest” relating to the property or transaction that is the subject 
7 
of the action; (3) the applicant must be situated such that disposition of the action may 
8 
impair or impede the party’s ability to protect that interest; and (4) the applicant’s interest 
9 
must not be adequately represented by existing parties. Arakaki v. Cayetano, 324 F.3d 
10 
1078, 1086 (9th Cir. 2003). An applicant seeking intervention bears the burden of proving 
11 
these requirements are met. Citizens for Balanced Use v. Mont. Wilderness Ass’n, 647 F.3d 
12 
893, 897 (9th Cir. 2011). Failure to satisfy any one of the requirements is fatal to the 
13 
application. Perry v. Prop. 8 Official Proponents, 587 F.3d 947, 950 (9th Cir. 2009).  
14 
Proposed Intervenors argue that they are entitled to intervene as of right in this 
15 
action because their Motion was filed at an early stage in the litigation, their interest in 
16 
ensuring the equity of athletic opportunity through sex segregation would be impaired if 
17 
Plaintiffs’ relief was granted, and the named Defendants will not adequately represent their 
18 
interests. (Doc. 98 at 9-16.) Plaintiffs argue that intervention as of right is not appropriate 
19 
because the Proposed Intervenors’ interest is not related to the Plaintiffs’ claim and because 
20 
the Legislators and Defendant Horne are vigorously defending the challenged Statute on 
21 
behalf of the State. (Doc. 130 at 4-8.)  
22 
Because  Proposed  Intervenors  have  not  proved  that  the  requirements  for 
23 
intervention are met, the Court will deny the application to intervene as of right. The 
24 
Proposed Intervenors have not satisfied the four-part test required to intervene as a matter 
25 
of right because: (1) their interest in ensuring the equality of athletic opportunity through 
26 
sex segregation is not related to Plaintiffs’ as-applied challenge; (2) granting Plaintiffs’ 
27 
requested  relief  would  not  practically  impair  Proposed  Intervenors’  interest;  and  (3) 
28 
 
- 3 - 

 
Case 4:23-cv-00185-JGZ   Document 160   Filed 10/23/23   Page 4 of 12
 
 
 
1  Defendant Horne and the Legislators who crafted the bill have expressed their commitment 
2  to vigorously defend the Statute. 
3 
A. Timeliness of Motion  
4 
“Courts weigh three factors in determining whether a motion to intervene is timely: 
5 
‘(1) the stage of the proceeding at which an applicant seeks to intervene; (2) the prejudice 
6 
to other parties; and (3) the reason for and length of delay.’” United States v. Alisal Water 
7 
Corp., 370  F.3d 915, 921 (9th Cir. 2004)  (citation omitted). “The  ‘crucial date’ for 
8 
determining timeliness is when the proposed intervenor ‘should have been aware that their 
9 
interests would not be adequately protected by the existing parties.’” Smith v. Los Angeles 
10 
Unified Sch. Dist., 830 F.3d 843, 854 (9th Cir. 2016) (quoting Smith v. Marsh, 194 F.3d 
11 
1045, 1052 (9th Cir. 1999)). “When considering prejudice to other parties, the Ninth Circuit 
12 
has held that the only ‘prejudice’ that is relevant . . . is that which flows from a prospective 
13 
intervenor’s failure to intervene after he knew, or reasonably should have known, that his 
14 
interests were not being adequately represented.” Kalbers v. United States Dep’t of Just., 
15 
22 F.4th 816, 825 (9th Cir. 2021). 
16 
As to the timing of the motion to intervene, Proposed Intervenors cite Ninth Circuit 
17 
case law that concluded “an intervention motion was timely when it was filed ‘less than 
18 
three months after the complaint was filed and less than two weeks after the [defendant] 
19 
filed its answer to the complaint.’” (Doc. 98 at 9-10); Citizens for Balanced Use v. Montana 
20 
Wilderness Ass’n, 647 F.3d 893, 897 (9th Cir. 2011) (quoting Prete v. Bradbury, 438 F.3d 
21 
949, 954 (9th Cir. 2006)). Proposed Intervenors argue that their motion to intervene meets 
22 
the Ninth Circuit’s “timeliness standard” because it was filed “less than eleven weeks after 
23 
the complaint was filed … about six weeks after Defendant Superintendent Horne filed his 
24 
answer to the complaint ….” (Doc. 98 at 10.) However, the “timeliness standard” that 
25 
Proposed Intervenors extrapolate from Ninth Circuit case law is relative and, as Plaintiffs 
26 
correctly point out, this particular case progressed significantly within the first three 
27 
months. Specifically, all parties appeared, the Legislators were granted limited permissive 
28 
intervention,  and  the  parties  addressed  and  briefed  substantive  issues  with  regard  to 
 
- 4 - 

 
Case 4:23-cv-00185-JGZ   Document 160   Filed 10/23/23   Page 5 of 12
 
 
 
1  Plaintiffs’ motion for preliminary injunction. (Doc. 79, 80.) The quick progression of this 
2  case is relevant.  
3  The Proposed Intervenors would or should have known whether their interests 
4  would be adequately protected by existing defendants. By their own account, prior to 
5  passage of the Statute, Proposed Intervenors spent substantial time and energy garnering 
6  support for the Statute, including giving a speech to the Arizona Senate committee, seeking 
7  witnesses to support the bill, and lobbying legislators. (Doc. 98 at 7-8). In light of their 
8  advocacy efforts, it is likely that Proposed Intervenors would have remained abreast of 
9  challenges to the Statute, particularly those made soon after the Statute’s implementation. 
10  Presumably, Proposed Intervenors would have determined whether their interests were 
11  adequately represented well before the three-month mark.   
12  Despite Proposed Intervenors’ delay in filing their motion, the Court finds that no 
13  substantial  prejudice  to  the  other  parties  would  result  from  Proposed  Intervenors’ 
14  involvement at this point in the litigation. Though Plaintiffs’ request for a preliminary 
15  injunction was granted, the merits of the case have yet to be briefed or argued. Additionally, 
16  Proposed Intervenors have stated that, if their motion is granted, they will collaborate with 
17  Defendants and take steps to avoid duplicative filings. (Doc. 138 at 10.) As such, the Court 
18  finds that the timeliness factor weighs slightly in favor of Plaintiffs, but is not dispositive.  
19 
B. Significantly Protectable Interest  
20 
Plaintiffs assert that because Jane Doe and Megan Roe bring an as-applied challenge 
21 
to the Statute, Proposed Intervenors’ daughters will not suffer any “direct, non-contingent, 
22 
and substantial” harm if the Court grants Plaintiffs’ requested relief. (Doc. 138 at 4.) The 
23 
Court agrees and finds that Proposed Intervenors have failed to establish that they would 
24 
be concretely affected if Plaintiffs are allowed to play on the girls’ sports teams at their 
25 
school.  
26 
Rule 24(a)(2) requires that the asserted interest be “protectable under some law” and 
27 
that there exist “a relationship between the legally protected interest and the claims at 
28 
issue.” Wilderness Soc'y v. U.S. Forest Serv., 630 F.3d 1173, 1179 (9th Cir. 2011). “If these 
 
- 5 - 

 
Case 4:23-cv-00185-JGZ   Document 160   Filed 10/23/23   Page 6 of 12
 
 
 
1  two core elements are not satisfied, a putative intervenor lacks any ‘interest’ under Rule 
2  24(a)(2).” California Dep't of Toxic Substances Control v. Jim Dobbas, Inc., 54 F.4th 1078, 
3  1088 (9th Cir. 2022). “[A]n undifferentiated, generalized interest in the outcome of an 
4  ongoing action is too porous a foundation on which to premise intervention as of right.” S. 
5  California Edison Co. v. Lynch, 307 F.3d 794, 803 (9th Cir. 2002) (quoting Public Serv. 
6  Co. of N.H. v. Patch, 136 F.3d 197, 205 (1st Cir. 1998)).  
7  Proposed Intervenors assert that, under Title IX, their interest in ensuring equality 
8  of athletic opportunity through sex segregation is a protectable interest. (Doc. 98 at 12.) 
9  Relying on California ex rel. Lockyer v. U.S., 450 F.3d 436 (9th Cir. 2006), they argue that 
10  their  protectable  interest  relates  to  Plaintiffs’  claims  because,  as  the  “intended 
11  beneficiaries” of the Statute (biological girls), their interest would be harmed if they were 
12  required to play with or against biological males in scholastic athletic competition. (Doc. 
13  138 at 2.)  
14  In California ex rel. Lockyer, health care providers moved to intervene in an action 
15  brought  by  the  state  of  California  challenging  the  constitutionality  of  a  federal 
16  appropriations rider enacted to protect the health care providers’ interests. 450 F.3d at 439. 
17  In holding that the health care workers had the right to intervene, the Ninth Circuit 
18  explained, “if the Amendment is declared unconstitutional … [health care providers] will 
19  be more likely to be forced to choose between adhering to their beliefs and losing their 
20  professional  licenses.  Such  an  interest  is  sufficiently  ‘direct,  non-contingent,  [and] 
21  substantial.’” Id. at 441.  
22  Unlike Lockyer, which dealt with a facial challenge to the constitutionality of a state 
23  statute,  here  Plaintiffs  bring  an  as-applied  challenge  to  the  Statute.  When  the 
24  constitutionality of a statute on its face is at issue, it necessarily follows that the intended 
25  beneficiaries of the statute would have a protectable interest in the outcome. Because this 
26  case involves an as-applied challenge, the outcome of the litigation will solely impact 
27  whether Jane Doe and Megan Roe can play school sports on girls’ teams. (See Doc. 1.) 
28  Significantly, if Plaintiffs prevail, Proposed Intervenors’ daughters will not be affected. 
 
- 6 - 

 
Case 4:23-cv-00185-JGZ   Document 160   Filed 10/23/23   Page 7 of 12
 
 
 
1  None of the Proposed Intervenors’ daughters will play on the same team as or compete 
2  against Jane Doe or Megan Roe. And the “possibility” that Mrs. Zenczak’s daughters will 
3  transfer to a school in the Kyrene district and compete with or against Plaintiffs is too 
4  attenuated to demonstrate an interest that is sufficiently “direct, non-contingent, [and] 
5  substantial.” (Doc. 98-4 ¶ 3); see Lockyer, 450 F.3d at 451. 
6  As the parents of girls who compete in school sports, and supporters of the Statute, 
7  Proposed Intervenors have only demonstrated a generalized interest in the outcome of the 
8  ongoing action. Ensuring equality of athletic opportunity is a universal interest held by all 
9  parents with children participating in school sports. This interest alone does not warrant 
10  intervention as a right in a lawsuit. As such, the Court finds that the Proposed Intervenors’ 
11  asserted interest does not relate to the Plaintiffs’ claims.   
12 
C. Practical Impairment of Interest 
13 
Proposed Intervenors state that if the Court grants Plaintiffs’ requested relief, Ms. 
14 
Van Hoek’s daughter may be forced to play against Jane Doe because she participates on 
15 
AIA sports teams. (Doc. 98 at 12.) Additionally, Mrs. Zenczak’s daughters may transfer to 
16 
a Kyrene school in which case they may compete with or against Jane Doe. (Id.) Further, 
17 
Proposed Intervenors claim that the decision on appeal will establish precedent in this case. 
18 
(Id.)  The  Court  concludes  that  Proposed  Intervenors’  interest  will  not  be  practically 
19 
impaired if Plaintiffs are granted relief in this action because the alleged harms are too 
20 
remote and because the decision of a district court does not have binding precedential 
21 
impact.  
22 
A party has a sufficient interest for intervention purposes if it will “suffer a practical 
23 
impairment of its interests as a result of the pending litigation.” Lockyer, 450 F.3d at 441. 
24 
The Ninth Circuit has said that although “a stare decisis effect is an important consideration 
25 
in  determining  the  extent  to  which  an  applicant’s  interest  may  be  impaired,”  the 
26 
precedential impact of a decision must be “clear.” United States v. State of Oregon, 839 
27 
F.2d 635, 638 (9th Cir. 1988); Green v. United States, 996 F.2d 973, 977 (9th Cir. 1993). 
28 
In the immediate case, it is unlikely that granting Plaintiffs’ requested relief would 
 
- 7 - 

 
Case 4:23-cv-00185-JGZ   Document 160   Filed 10/23/23   Page 8 of 12
 
 
 
1  impair Proposed Intervenors’ interests. As noted above, Proposed Intervenors do not allege 
2  that their daughters attend the same school as Plaintiffs or compete against Plaintiffs’ 
3  schools. Van Hoek’s younger daughter attends a high school that is part of the AIA, but 
4  she plays softball and thus will not compete against either Jane Doe or Megan Roe, who 
5  do not. (Doc. 98-2 ¶ 3). And the “possibility” that Mrs. Zenczak’s daughters will transfer 
6  to a Kyrene school and compete with or against Plaintiffs is too attenuated to constitute an 
7  impediment to Proposed Intervenors’ interests. (Doc. 98 at 12.) Moreover, while the Court 
8  recognizes that stare decisis is an important consideration, Proposed Intervenors fail to 
9  establish a clear precedential impact. “A decision of a federal district court judge is not 
10  binding precedent in either a different judicial district, the same judicial district, or even 
11  upon the same judge in a different case.” Camreta v. Greene, 563 U.S. 692, 709 n.7 (2011). 
12  Although there remains the possibility that the Ninth Circuit will eventually review this 
13  Court’s decision (as is the case with any litigation in this circuit), this is too speculative to 
14  support  Proposed  Intervenors’  claim  that  their  interest  would  be  impaired  without 
15  intervention. This is particularly true where the challenge is an as-applied challenge. Thus, 
16  Proposed Intervenors have not established that their practical interest would be impaired if 
17  the Court granted Plaintiffs’ requested relief.  
18 
D. Adequate Representation 
19 
Since Proposed Intervenors filed their motion to intervene, the Court has permitted 
20 
the Legislators to intervene as a permanent party to the litigation. The Legislators, in 
21 
addition to Defendant Horne, will adequately represent the interests of the Proposed 
22 
Intervenors because these parties share the same “ultimate goal” in the litigation. In fact, 
23 
Defendant Horne and the Legislators have vowed to vigorously defend the constitutionality 
24 
of the Statute on behalf of their constituents.  
25 
In  assessing  the  adequacy  of  representation,  the  Ninth  Circuit  considers  three 
26 
factors: “(1) whether the interest of a present party is such that it will undoubtedly make 
27 
all of a proposed intervenor’s arguments; (2) whether the present party is capable and 
28 
willing to make such arguments; and (3) whether a proposed intervenor would offer any 
 
- 8 - 

 
Case 4:23-cv-00185-JGZ   Document 160   Filed 10/23/23   Page 9 of 12
 
 
 
1  necessary elements to the proceeding that other parties would neglect.” Arakaki, 324 F.3d 
2  at 1086. The “most important factor” in assessing the adequacy of representation is “how 
3  the interest compares with the interests of existing parties.” Arakaki, 324 F.3d at 1086. If 
4  an applicant for intervention and an existing party share the same ultimate objective, a 
5  presumption of adequacy of representation arises. League of United Latin Am. Citizens v. 
6  Wilson, 131 F.3d 1297, 1305 (9th Cir. 1997). “There is also an assumption of adequacy 
7  when the government is acting on behalf of a constituency that it represents ….” Citizens 
8  for Balanced Use, 647 F.3d at 898. To rebut the presumption, an applicant must make a 
9  “compelling showing” of inadequacy of representation. Arakaki, 324 F.3d at 1086.  
10  Proposed Intervenors do not dispute that they share the same ultimate objective as 
11  Defendants Horne and the Legislators—defending the constitutionality of the Statute being 
12  challenged  by  Plaintiffs.  Thus,  Proposed  Intervenors  must  rebut  the  presumption  of 
13  adequacy with a compelling showing. For this purpose, Proposed Intervenors advance three 
14  arguments: (1) Defendants will not make the same arguments as Proposed Intervenors 
15  because Defendants represent a broader constituency; (2) Defendant Horne is not capable 
16  of making such arguments due to financial constraints; and (3) Defendant Horne will not 
17  adequately represent the perspective of biological girls. (Doc. 98 at 14-16; Doc. 138 at 4-
18  6.) 
19  First, there is no basis to find that the Legislators and Defendant Horne will not 
20  make the same arguments proposed by the Proposed Intervenors as this case proceeds. 
21  Though Proposed Intervenors contend that the Legislators represent a “much broader 
22  constituency” which will “factor into how they respond to this action,” the Court finds no 
23  reason to believe that the Legislators would forgo any argument that Proposed Intervenors 
24  would  make.  (Doc.  138  at  5.)  Indeed,  as  evidenced  by  the  briefing  submitted  by 
25  Defendants, as well as the motion to dismiss submitted by Proposed Intervenors, Proposed 
26  Intervenors fail to articulate any argument that Defendant Horne or the State Legislators 
27  have  not  already  made.  Accordingly,  Proposed  Intervenors’  involvement  would  be 
28  unnecessary and redundant.  
 
- 9 - 

 
Case 4:23-cv-00185-JGZ   Document 160   Filed 10/23/23   Page 10 of 12
 
 
 
1  Additionally, the Legislators considered the Proposed Intervenors’ views when they 
2  crafted the Statute at issue. Proposed Intervenors individually, and AWOA as a whole, 
3  have been active in their support for the Save Women’s Sports Act. Ms. Zenczak “gave a 
4  speech to an Arizona Senate committee in favor of the Act,” and Ms. Fink has “[sought] 
5  witnesses to testify in support of the bill … and also email[ed] and call[ed] legislators in 
6  support of the bill.” (Doc. 98 at 7). The Legislators have expressed their commitment to 
7  vigorously defend the Statute stating “[they] have a crucial interest in … defending the 
8  constitutionality of state statutes” on behalf of their constituents. (Doc. 19 at 11.) Proposed 
9  Intervenors do not demonstrate that their interest differs from the Legislators or that the 
10  Legislators will fail to defend the bill with equal zealousness. 
11  Second, Proposed Intervenors argue that Defendant Horne is not capable of making 
12  the parent representatives arguments because he lacks the financial resources to do so. 
13  (Doc. 98 at 15.) Plaintiffs assert that this argument has already been disposed of by this 
14  Court—and the Court agrees. A.R.S. § 41-192(E) provides that, in the event that the 
15  attorney general is disqualified, “the state agency is authorized to make expenditures and 
16  incur indebtedness to employ attorneys to provide the representation or services.” Indeed, 
17  Defendant Horne has retained counsel, filed several motions, answered the complaint, and 
18  confirmed his intention to vigorously defend this lawsuit in the press. Moreover, the 
19  Legislators have been permitted to intervene. Defendant Horne and the Legislators are 
20  capable of adequately representing the Proposed Intervenors’ interests, which align with 
21  those of Defendant Horne and the Legislators.  
22  Finally, Proposed Intervenors argue that they would “bring to this case the vital 
23  perspective of biological females,” an element that Defendant Horne would neglect. (Doc. 
24  98 at 16.) The Court is unconvinced that Defendants would neglect the perspective of 
25  biological  females.  On  the  contrary,  this  perspective  has  already  been  addressed  in 
26  Defendants’ briefing on Plaintiffs’ motion for a preliminary injunction. Specifically, the 
27  Legislators argued that “[h]aving separate sex specific teams furthers efforts to promote 
28  sex equality by providing opportunities for female athletes to demonstrate their skill, 
 
- 10 - 

 
Case 4:23-cv-00185-JGZ   Document 160   Filed 10/23/23   Page 11 of 12
 
 
 
1  strength and athletic abilities while also providing them with opportunities to obtain 
2  recognition, accolades, college scholarships and the numerous other long-term benefits that 
3  flow from success in athletic endeavors.” (Doc. 82 at 12.) Simply because an individual 
4  with a particular perspective is not made party to the litigation does not mean that their 
5  interest  will  not  be  adequately  protected  by  existing  parties.  Here,  Defendants  have 
6  demonstrated that they will represent the perspective of biological girls in the litigation. As 
7  such, there is no reason to believe that Defendants would neglect elements that would 
8  otherwise be raised by Proposed Intervenors.  
9  In sum, Proposed Intervenors have not made a compelling showing that their interest 
10  will  not  be  adequately  protected  by  Defendants.  Accordingly,  the  Court  will  deny 
11  intervention as of right under rule 24(a).  
12 
II.  Permissive Intervention 
13 
Unlike  intervention  as  of  right,  permissive  intervention  under  Rule  24(b)  is 
14 
discretionary.  A  district  court  may  permit  intervention  if  the  movant,  “on  a  timely 
15 
motion…has a claim or defense that shares with the main action a common question of law 
16 
or fact.” Fed. R. Civ. P. 24(b). The court must consider whether the intervention will unduly 
17 
delay or prejudice the adjudication of the original parties’ rights. Dep’t of Fair Employment 
18 
& Hous. v. Lucent Techs., Inc., 642 F.3d 728, 741 (9th Cir. 2011).  
19 
If  the  initial  conditions  are  met,  the  court  may  also  consider  “whether  the 
20 
intervenors’ interests are adequately represented by other parties … and whether parties 
21 
seeking intervention will significantly contribute to full development of the underlying 
22 
factual issues in the suit and to the just and equitable adjudication of the legal questions 
23 
presented.” Callahan v. Brookdale Senior Living Cmtys., 38 F.4th 813, 822 (9th Cir. 2022). 
24 
Proposed Intervenors have established that they have a claim or defense that shares 
25 
a common question of law or fact with the main action, and their permissive intervention 
26 
at this stage in the case would not unduly delay or prejudice the original parties. However, 
27 
such  intervention  is  unnecessary  because,  as  explained  in  Section  I,  the  Proposed 
28 
Intervenors’ interests will be adequately represented by the Legislators and Defendant 
 
- 11 - 

 
Case 4:23-cv-00185-JGZ   Document 160   Filed 10/23/23   Page 12 of 12
 
 
 
1  Horne. Moreover, participation of Proposed Intervenors is not necessary to fully develop 
2  the underlying factual issues in the suit. On the contrary, permitting intervention by 
3  Proposed Intervenors would likely result in redundant and unnecessary efforts.  
4  Accordingly, the Court will deny Proposed Intervenors application for permissive 
5  intervention under Rule 24(b).  
6  CONCLUSION 
7  For the foregoing reasons, Proposed Intervenors Motion to Intervene (Doc. 98) is 
8  DENIED.  
9    Dated this 20th day of October, 2023.

documents.title: Order
documents.text:
Case 4:23-cv-00185-JGZ   Document 213   Filed 06/21/24   Page 1 of 8
 
 
 
1  WO 
2   
3   
4   
5   
6  IN THE UNITED STATES DISTRICT COURT 
7  FOR THE DISTRICT OF ARIZONA 
 
8 
 
9  Helen Doe, et al.,  No. CV-23-00185-TUC-JGZ 
   
10  Plaintiffs,  ORDER  
   
11  v.  
 
12  Thomas C Horne, et al., 
 
13  Defendants. 
 
14   
15 
Pending before the Court is Intervenor-Defendants’ 12(b)(6) Motion to Dismiss. 
16  (Doc. 146.) Intervenor-Defendants argue Plaintiffs fail to state ADA and Rehabilitation 
17  Act claims in Count III of their Complaint because: (1) gender dysphoria is excluded from 
18  ADA coverage under 42 U.S.C. § 12211(b); (2) Plaintiffs do not allege that their gender 
19  identity disorder results from a physical impairment; and (3) Plaintiffs do not allege that a 
20  major life activity has been substantially limited. (See id.)1 The Motion is fully briefed. 
21  (Doc. 146, 150, 157.) For the reasons that follow, the Court will deny the Motion. (Doc. 
22  146.) The Court concludes that Plaintiffs plausibly state claims under the ADA and the 
23  Rehabilitation Act in their Complaint.  
24 
25 
 
1 Intervenor-Defendants also argue for dismissal of Plaintiff’s Equal Protection Claim 
26 
(Count I) and Title IX Claim (Count II) for the reasons set out in the opposition to 
Plaintiffs’ preliminary injunction motion. (Doc. 146 at 11.) As Intervenor-Defendants 
27 
acknowledge,  the  Court  considered  and  rejected  those  arguments  in  resolving  the 
preliminary injunction motion. (Doc. 127.)  The Court, therefore, will not revisit the 
28 
arguments here.  
 
 

 
Case 4:23-cv-00185-JGZ   Document 213   Filed 06/21/24   Page 2 of 8
 
 
 
1   
2  BACKGROUND 
3  Plaintiffs filed this action for declaratory and injunction relief, asserting A.R.S. § 
4  15-120.02 violates their rights under the Equal Protection Clause, Title IX, the Americans 
5  With Disabilities Act (ADA), and Section 504 of the Rehabilitation Act (RA). (See Doc. 
6  1.) A.R.S. § 15-120.02 provides that interscholastic or intramural “[a]thletic teams or sports 
7  designated for ‘females’, ‘women’ or ‘girls’ may not be open to students of the male sex.” 
8  (Doc. 1 at 2.)  If enforced, A.R.S. § 15-120.02 would prohibit Plaintiffs, two transgender 
9  girls, from participating on girls’ sports teams.  
10  STANDARD OF REVIEW 
Under Rule 12(b)(6), a party may move to dismiss a claim for relief by asserting 
11 
“failure to state a claim upon which relief can be granted.” Fed. R. Civ. P. 12(b)(6). “To 
12 
survive a motion to dismiss, a complaint must contain sufficient factual matter, accepted 
13 
as true, to ‘state a claim to relief that is plausible on its face.’” Ashcroft v. Iqbal, 556 U.S. 
14 
662, 678 (2009) (quoting Bell Atlantic Corp. v. Twombly, 550 U.S. 544, 570 (2007)). “A 
15 
claim has facial plausibility when the plaintiff pleads factual content that allows the court 
16 
to draw the reasonable inference that the defendant is liable for the misconduct alleged.” 
17 
Id. In considering a Rule 12(b)(6) motion, the Court must “accept factual allegations in the 
18 
complaint as true and construe the pleadings in the light most favorable to the nonmoving 
19 
party.” Manzarek v. St. Paul Fire & Marine Ins. Co., 519 F.3d 1025, 1031 (9th Cir. 2008). 
20 
Dismissal can be based on the lack of a cognizable legal theory or the absence of sufficient 
21 
facts alleged under a cognizable legal theory. Balistreri v. Pacifica Police Dep't, 901 F.2d 
22 
696, 699 (9th Cir. 1988) (internal citation omitted). 
23 
DISCUSSION 
24 
I.  Plaintiffs plausibly allege that A.R.S. § 15-120.02 violates their rights under the 
25 
ADA and Rehabilitation Act.  
26 
A.  The ADA and the Rehabilitation Act  
27 
The ADA provides that “no qualified individual with a disability shall, by reason of 
28  such disability, be excluded from participation in or be denied the benefits of the services, 
 
- 2 - 

 
Case 4:23-cv-00185-JGZ   Document 213   Filed 06/21/24   Page 3 of 8
 
 
 
1  programs, or activities of a public entity, or be subjected to discrimination by any such 
2  entity.” 42 U.S.C. § 12132. Section 504 of the Rehabilitation Act similarly provides:  “No 
3  otherwise qualified individual with a disability . . . shall, solely by reason of her or his 
4  disability, be excluded from the participation in, be denied the benefits of, or be subjected 
5  to discrimination under any program or activity receiving Federal financial assistance.” 29 
6  U.S.C. § 794(a). Generally, the same legal principles govern ADA and Rehabilitation Act 
7  claims. M.R. v. Dreyfus, 697 F.3d 706, 733 (9th Cir. 2012). “Because the applicable 
8  provisions of the ADA and the Rehabilitation Act are ‘co-extensive,’ [courts] discuss both 
9  claims together, focusing on the ADA.” Id. To establish a discrimination claim under either 
10  the ADA or the RA, Plaintiffs must establish that (1) they have a disability; (2) they were 
excluded from participation in or denied the benefits of the services, programs, or activities 
11 
of a public entity; and (3) the exclusion, denial, or discrimination was by reason of their 
12 
disability. Where Do We Go Berkeley v. Cal. Dep't of Transp., 32 F.4th 852, 860 (9th Cir. 
13 
2022) (quoting Duvall v. Cnty. of Kitsap, 260 F.3d 1124, 1135 (9th Cir. 2001)). 
14 
B. Gender dysphoria is not excluded under the ADA. 
15 
Intervenor-Defendants argue that Plaintiffs’ gender dysphoria is not a “disability” 
16 
under the ADA because Section 12211(b) excludes from the definition of disability: 
17 
“transvestism,  transsexualism,  pedophilia,  exhibitionism,  voyeurism,  gender  identity 
18 
disorders not resulting from physical impairments, or other sexual behavior disorders.” 42 
19 
U.S.C.  §  12211(b).    Although  gender  dysphoria  is  not  listed  in  Section  12211(b), 
20 
Intervenor-Defendants argue that Congress intended to include gender dysphoria in the list 
21 
of  excluded  conditions.  (Doc.  146  at  3.)    The  Fourth  Circuit  addressed  these  same 
22 
arguments in Williams v. Kincaid, 45 F.4th 759, 766 (4th Cir. 2022), cert. denied, 143 S. 
23 
Ct. 2414 (2023).  The Court agrees with that court’s analysis and concludes that gender 
24 
dysphoria is not excluded from coverage by Section 12211(b). 
25 
1.   Section 12211(b) does not explicitly exclude gender dysphoria.  
26 
The text of Section 12211(b) does not mention “gender dysphoria.” See 42 U.S.C. 
27 
§ 12211; see Williams, 45 F.4th at 766–67 (“Although the ADA specifically lists a number 
28 
of  exclusions  from  the  definition  of  disability,  that  list  does  not  include  gender 
 
- 3 - 

 
Case 4:23-cv-00185-JGZ   Document 213   Filed 06/21/24   Page 4 of 8
 
 
 
1  dysphoria.”).  Adding  “gender  dysphoria”  to  the  list  of  ADA  exclusions  would 
2  impermissibly rewrite what Congress has chosen not to rewrite. See U.S. v. Watkins, 278 
3  F.3d 961, 965 (9th Cir. 2002) (it is a canon of statutory construction that words should not 
4  be added to or read into a statute.) 
5  Intervenor-Defendants argue that “gender dysphoria” is excludable as a “gender 
6  identity disorder not resulting from physical impairments.” (Doc. 146 at 2-5.) However, 
7  this Court finds support for the conclusion that “gender dysphoria” is distinct from the 
8  category of “gender identity disorders.”  
9  The ADA does not define “gender identity disorders.” As such, the Court looks to 
10  the meaning of the ADA's “terms at the time of its enactment.” Bostock v. Clayton County, 
140 S. Ct. 1731, 1738 (2020). The contemporary medical definitions are contained in the 
11 
American Psychiatric Association’s Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders 
12 
(“DSM”). When the ADA was enacted in 1990, the DSM-3 did not recognize gender 
13 
dysphoria as a diagnosis. See Williams, 45 F.4th at 767. Rather, the DSM-3 recognized 
14 
“gender identity disorders,” of which the essential feature is “an incongruence between 
15 
assigned sex and gender identity.” Id. (citing Am. Psych. Ass'n, Diagnostic and Statistical 
16 
Manual 71 (3d ed., rev. 1987) (DSM-III-R)).  
17 
In 2013, the American Psychiatric Association removed “gender identity disorders” 
18 
from the DSM-5 and added “gender dysphoria” as a diagnosis. Williams, 45 F.4th at 767; 
19 
see Am. Psych. Ass'n, Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders 451 (5th ed., 
20 
2013) (DSM-5). Intervenor-Defendants argue the term “gender dysphoria” replaced the 
21 
term “gender identity disorder”  and did not create a new diagnosis. (Doc. 157 at 2.) Though 
22 
the DSM-5’s replacement of “gender identity disorder” with “gender dysphoria” reflected 
23 
a shift in medical understanding, the revision was not simply semantic. Indeed, as the 
24 
Fourth  Circuit  noted  in  Williams,  such  a  reading  ignores  the  substantive  differences 
25 
between the two diagnoses. 45 F.4th at 767.  
26 
Gender  identity  disorders  and  gender  dysphoria  are  characterized  by  different 
27 
symptoms. Gender dysphoria is distinct from a “gender identity disorder” because it goes 
28 
beyond  merely  identifying  with  a  different  gender;  the  essential  element  of  “gender 
 
- 4 - 

 
Case 4:23-cv-00185-JGZ   Document 213   Filed 06/21/24   Page 5 of 8
 
 
 
1  dysphoria”  is  the  “clinically  significant  distress”  felt  by  those  who  experience  an 
2  incongruence between their assigned sex and their gender identity. DSM-5 at 451–53. The 
3  DSM-5 explains that the distress caused by gender dysphoria may result in intense anxiety, 
4  depression, suicidal ideation, and even suicide. DSM-5 at 454–55. Further, when left 
5  untreated,  gender  dysphoria  can  expose  transgender  individuals  to  a  serious  risk  of 
6  psychological and physical harm. See Edmo v. Corizon, Inc., 935 F.3d 757, 771 (9th Cir. 
7  2019). Prior to the DSM-5, there was no diagnosis for these distress symptoms. See 
8  Williams, 45 F.4th at 767. Thus, while the DSM-3 “pathologized the very existence of 
9  transgender people,” the DSM-5 “focuses on the dysphoria as the clinical problem, not 
10  identity per se.” Id. at 768-69 (noting not all transgender individuals will experience 
distress as a result of gender incongruence, but for some, the incongruence results in gender 
11 
dysphoria); DSM-5 at 451. Notably, in 2009, Congress amended the ADA, instructing 
12 
courts that the definition of “disability” “shall be construed in favor of broad coverage of 
13 
individuals under this chapter, to the maximum extent permitted by the [ADA's] terms.” 
14 
42 U.S.C. § 12102(4)(A).  For all of these reasons, the Court concludes that gender 
15 
dysphoria does not fall under the category of “gender identity disorders” as conceived at 
16 
the time of the ADA’s enactment.  
17 
3. Gender dysphoria does not belong in the category of “other sexual 
18 
behavioral disorders.” 
19 
  Intervenor-defendants argue that Section 12211(b)’s exclusion of “other sexual 
20 
behavior  disorders”  shows  Congress’s  intent  to  prohibit  the  ADA’s  application  to 
21 
conditions that are sufficiently similar to the more specific categories of conditions that 
22 
precede it. (Doc. 146 at 5.) Intervenor-Defendants assert that gender dysphoria is an 
23 
excluded condition under this catchall provision. (Id.) However, there is support for the 
24 
conclusion  that  gender  dysphoria  is  not  sufficiently  similar  to  “transvestism, 
25 
transsexualism, pedophilia, exhibitionism, and voyeurism” to be included in the catchall 
26 
provision. See 42 U.S.C. § 12211(b).  
27 
The phrase “other sexual behavioral disorders” serves as a qualifier that emphasizes 
28 
the behavioral component of the explicitly excluded “sexual disorders.” See § 12211 
 
- 5 - 

 
Case 4:23-cv-00185-JGZ   Document 213   Filed 06/21/24   Page 6 of 8
 
 
 
1  (b)(1); see also Kozak v. CSX Transportation, Inc., 2023 WL 4906148, at *6 (W.D.N.Y. 
2  Aug. 1, 2023) (“[A]t the end [of Section 12211] is a qualifier that applies to the entire 
3  series: ‘or other sexual behavior disorders,’” suggesting that “Section 12211 is a list of 
4  behavior  disorders,”  with  a  “behavioral  component.”).  The  essential  element  of 
5  “transvestism” is the urge to cross-dress, see DSM-III-R-at 288; the essential element of 
6  “transsexualism” is the urge to live as a member of the opposite sex (often accomplished 
7  through cross-dress or sex reassignment), see DSM-III-R at 74; see also Kozak, 2023 WL 
8  4906148, at *6 (“'Transsexualism,’ as understood in 1987 . . . involved a behavioral 
9  component.”); the essential element of “pedophilia” is the urge to engage in sexual activity 
10  with a prepubescent child, DSM-III-R at 284; the essential element of “exhibitionism” is 
the urge to expose one's genitals to a stranger, DSM-III-R 282; and the essential element 
11 
of “voyeurism” is the urge to observe people who are either naked, disrobing, or engaged 
12 
in sexual activity, DSM-III-R 289. Gender dysphoria is not characterized as a behavioral 
13 
disorder. See DSM-5; Kozak, WL 4906148, at *7 (“Gender dysphoria . . . has no behavioral 
14 
component” and “cannot be understood as a falling within the broad category of ‘sexual 
15 
behavior disorders.’”). As explained above, the essential element of gender dysphoria is 
16 
the “clinical distress” resulting from an individual’s discordant gender identity. DSM-5 at 
17 
451–53. Finally, as noted above, Congress instructed the courts to construe the definition 
18 
of  “disability”  in  favor  of  broad  coverage  in  its  2009  amendment.  See  42  U.S.C. 
19 
§ 12102(4)(A).  Thus, this Court finds that gender dysphoria is not included in the catchall 
20 
category “other sexual behavioral disorders,” or excluded as a disability.  
21 
C. Plaintiffs properly allege they have a qualifying disability.   
22 
Intervenor-Defendants dispute Plaintiffs’ allegation that they have a qualifying 
23 
disability under the ADA and RA because they do not specify “which major life activity 
24 
has been impaired.” (Doc. 146 at 8-10.) Intervenor-Defendants assert that “playing sports” 
25 
is not a substantial life activity. (Doc. 146 at 10.) 
26 
A disability is “a physical or mental impairment that substantially limits one or more 
27 
major life activities.” 42 U.S.C. § 12102. Major life activities include, but are not limited 
28 
to,  caring  for  oneself,  eating,  sleeping,  learning,  reading,  concentrating,  thinking, 
 
- 6 - 

 
Case 4:23-cv-00185-JGZ   Document 213   Filed 06/21/24   Page 7 of 8
 
 
 
1  communicating,  and  working.  42  U.S.C.  §  12102  (2)(A).  The  applicable  regulations 
2  instruct: “[t]he term ‘substantially limits’ shall be construed broadly in favor of expansive 
3  coverage, to the maximum extent permitted by the terms of the ADA. ‘Substantially limits’ 
4  is not meant to be a demanding standard.” 29 C.F.R. § 1630.2 (j)(1)(i).  
5  Plaintiffs plausibly allege that they have a disability that substantially limits one or 
6  more major life activities. See 42 U.S.C. § 12102(A). Plaintiffs allege that they suffer from 
7  gender dysphoria. (See Doc. 1 at 12 (“Jane was diagnosed with gender dysphoria when she 
8  was seven years old and has lived her life as a girl since she was five years old.”) and Doc. 
9  1 at 14 (“[Megan] was diagnosed with gender dysphoria when she was 10 years old,” and 
10  “has been receiving puberty-blocking medication since she was 11 years old,” as part of 
her medically-prescribed treatment).) Gender dysphoria is a condition recognized by the 
11 
American Psychiatric Association, and is described in the DSM-5 as characterized by 
12 
“clinically significant distress.” DSM-5 at 451. Symptoms of gender dysphoria include 
13 
anxiety, depression, eating disorders, substance abuse, self-harm, and suicide. (Doc. 1 at 
14 
8); see DSM-5 at 451-59. These symptoms may substantially limit major life activities 
15 
including, but not limited to, eating, sleeping, learning, reading, concentrating, thinking, 
16 
communicating, and working. (Doc. 150 at 12.) In fact, the DSM-5 states that the functional 
17 
consequences of gender dysphoria include “interfere[nce] with daily activities.”  DSM-5 
18 
at  454-454.  Because  Plaintiffs  suffer  from  gender  dysphoria,  and  gender  dysphoria 
19 
manifests  in  symptoms  that  interfere  with  daily  activities,  the  Court  concludes  that 
20 
Plaintiffs have sufficiently allege that they have a qualifying disability under the ADA.   
21 
Intervenor-Defendants’  assertion  that  “playing  sports”  is  not  a  substantial  life 
22 
activity  confuses  the  analysis.  (Doc.  146  at  9.)  The  ADA  and  RA  do  not  prohibit 
23 
discrimination in the provision of “major life activities.” Rather, the ADA and RA prohibit 
24 
covered entities from precluding qualified individuals with a disability from participating 
25 
in a program, service, or activity, or otherwise discriminating against them because of their 
26 
disability.  See Furgess v. Pa. Dep't of  Corr., 933 F.3d 285, 288–89 (3d Cir. 2019) 
27 
(emphasis added). The issue is not whether “playing sports” is a major life activity, but 
28 
rather, whether “playing sports” is an activity from which Plaintiffs have been excluded 
 
- 7 - 

 
Case 4:23-cv-00185-JGZ   Document 213   Filed 06/21/24   Page 8 of 8
 
 
 
1  based on their disability. The Court finds that Plaintiffs have sufficiently alleged that they 
2  suffer from gender dysphoria, and that gender dysphoria qualifies as a disability under the 
3  ADA and RA. Accordingly,  
4  IT IS ORDERED Intervenor-Defendants’ Motion to Dismiss (Doc. 146) is denied.  
5  IT IS FURTHER ORDERED Intervenor-Defendants must file an Answer to the 
6  Complaint on or before July 15, 2024.   
7    Dated this 21st day of June, 2024. 
8   
9
